title: Which country will win the 2020 Olympic gold medal in women's football (soccer)?

To get my initial forecast for the gold medal team I averaged the odds given by 3 major sportsbooks for each team to win gold (after normalizing the sum of percentages to 100% to "de-vig" the odds). Then I considered the no medal awarded possibility, which only seems possible to me if the event gets cancelled: which would most likely be due to COVID cases in the women's soccer teams or the entire Olympics being cancelled. Since the Olympics have already started despite a lack of popular support from the Japanese populace, however COVID-19 cases are still on the rise in the country. With that being said I assess that there's a less than 1% chance the entire Olympics get cancelled.

Basically, Sweden is performing amazingly. The US not so much.  I've also reduced the estimate for the Netherlands because they seem to receive goals as well, although their offense seems to be very strong: +20 goals in 3 games. But also received 8 goals as well. In play-off rounds, this could prove fatal.  GB is okay, but they'll be (probably) facing Sweden in semi-final.  I'd say two of the followings will go into the final: Sweden, Netherlands, Brazil (most likely Sweden vs. Netherlands)

GB vs Australia          Or       Sweden vs Japan                                 to play                Netherlands vs USA     Or  Canada  vs Brazil US still very much out of sorts, but only 3 wins needed for anybody to become Champions.   I'll move US back above 50% if they get past the Netherlands.

After the first two games of pool play, I've adjusted my percentages based on results.  Looking back at previous Olympic results, the winner of the tournament has dropped at least 1 game in pool play 3 of the last 4 tournaments.  Therefore, I am not too concerned about the United States dropping a game to Sweden and still believe they are the strongest team in the tournament.  However, the winner of the tournament has also been the winner of their group 3/4 times, which it is not looking like the United States is going to do (therefore the United States will have a tougher first round matchup in knockout rounds).  So this has caused me to degrade the United States relative to my previous prediction.  Likewise, strong performance from GB, Netherlands, Sweden, and Brazil has caused me to upgrade all of their rankings.  Finally, Japan has been very underwhelming and will most likely qualify for the quarterfinals as a 3rd seed.  This means they will play one of the top two teams in the tournament, making it very difficult for them to move on.  Thus, I've made some adjustments to all of my initial predictions.  As more results come out, I will continue to adjust as needed.

Base rates were calculated based on normalized betting odds. Other countries that have marginal odds include Brazil, Sweden, and Canada, which seemed to be initially disregarded. Base rates were slightly adjusted to account for the fact that the US has won the majority of all Olympic gold medals (4/6), but not by too much as historical precedent is probably well accounted for in betting odds. The most important adjustment made was on "momentum" of current results. So a team that has accumulated a tough win in the group stages would be assigned a slightly higher probability, and vice-versa.

Looking like GB, Canada or Sweden to make it to the final in the top half of draw after second round of group games - so making sure they have 40% of total between them.  US bounced back to beat NZ and probably still the team to beat

I've adjusted my probabilities using updated betting odds off of sports betting websites. These price in the various confounding factors that influence these games, that I would not be aware of (injuries, previous matches, etc.)

I used some betting odds for initial estimates for the projections, but ended up adjusting according to the chance that the olympics would not occur. All other events (potential injuries, etc.) are likely accounted for in the projections themselves. I made sure to normalize the odds before calculating the probabilities.

Used betting odds and then modified according to current estimates on the Olympics being cancelled. Drug tests will often result in silver being promoted to gold, so it is unlikely for gold not to be awarded *if the event is held*.

To get a baseline for this statistic, I looked at some betting odds for the Olympics. While these are not perfect metrics, these do have a general sense of how good these teams are and their general chances of winning. Looking back over the previous Women's World Cup and Women's Olympics (same rules and age requirements), 8/14 of these previous competitions have been won by the United States, and the United States has won the most recent one just two years ago. On top of that, they have more depth than other teams as well so while injuries may hurt them. That being said, there is still some randomness in soccer and there are lots of other strong competitors (Great Britain, Japan, Netherlands)  that have a solid chance which gave me the following odds. Additionally, there is also a marginal chance that the Olympics is cancelled and no gold medal is awarded to any team.

Using betting odds (+700, +700, +500, +100 for GB, Japan, the Netherlands, and the US, respectively), I calculated the above percentages and scaled them by my current forecast for the Olympics not occurring. My previous estimate was 2% for this, but the time to the games has halved, so I now estimate 1%.

I simply used betting odds for which teams had the best chance of winning the tournament. The betting odds were a few days old, so I checked to make sure there wasn't a ton of news since then. The US and Brazil roster actually got announced since the money lines were updated, but there was nothing surprising there so it didn't change my estimates. I then scaled everything by the chance the Olympics don't happen, which I would place around 4% right now since we're less than a month away, athletes have been selected and announced for all sports, and there hasn't been significant news from IOC or Japan.

Methodology: 
1. Find past statistics for Olympics. Compute a weighted score for each country based on medals attained (1 weight for gold, e^-1 for silver, e^-2 for bronze, e^-3 for 4th place). 
2. Find current FIFA ranking for each country
3. Compute a weighted sum, 0.95 * FIFA ranking + 0.05 * Olympic weighted score (this weighting is arbitrary but designed to capture a little bit of Olympic history)

My initial estimates are based on the current ranking of Fifa and the following facts: https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/ranking-table/women/ US is the top team, and they've dominated the women football for a long time, so they're the favorite, and they have 4 of the current top 10 best players in the world. The Netherlands are the 3rd team on the raking - Germany is the 2nd and the defending champion, but they didn't qualify. England is the 6th team, but they've mixed with other UK countries, so their chance increases Other countries such as Sweden or Brazil are also likely to win - Brazil has 2 players who are among top10 best players at the moment: https://olympics.com/en/featured-news/womens-football-players-follow-social-media

Just using betting odds for now. It's super early, rosters are just now being finalized, and the competition hasn't been around long enough and is too infrequent to get good outside rates. The knockout stage seeding also makes it unlikely that anyone would get screwed by their group seeding since two of the three 3rd place finishers will still advance to knockouts.  https://dknation.draftkings.com/2021/6/9/22525792/olympics-mens-volleyball-gold-medal-odds-tokyo-2021-team-usa-poland-brazil-russia-france For converting betting odds to probabilities: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1281084

After thinking more about my prediction, I think the US should be considered even heavier favorites.  Winning 3/4 of the previous gold medals suggests a 75% win rate.  Likewise, the United States has won the last 2 world cups (and lost in the final 3 world cups ago).  Considering that these tournaments function similarly, this gives an estimated win rate of roughly 5/7 or 71% win rate at major tournaments.  This pushed me to increase my estimated win rate to 60%.  One reason I estimate lower than my base rate is that the women's team has had a longer layoff between major tournaments than normal, and their schedule has been less competitive than normal as of late.  Therefore, I think the team could be slightly rusty and susceptible to an upset.   After readjusting my USA estimate, I left the proportions of my previous predictions the same.

The USA women's team has won 3 of the last 4 olympics and is the #1 ranked team in the world.  They're also the defending World Cup champions.  In recent history, they have been utterly dominant.  Further, betting odds have them as the heavy favorites to win at +100 (which suggests they are nearly a 50% favorite to win when taking the vig into account).  Knowing less about the other countries' recent performance, I made predictions based on research of previous results and betting odds.  Finally, I believe there is a 5% chance that the Olympics are delayed, which is why I've given 'No gold medal' that probability.
Upping Netherlands after their 7-0 win vs traditionally strong Norway last night.
